channel.title: Posts on RICH RYAN
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on RICH RYAN

item.title: Facts from the Employment Situation
item.description: Here are a few facts from the most recent Employment Situation. The latest data on labor-force participation, highlighted in this Brookings post, and the employment-population ratio are depicted below. # Load packages library(tidyverse) library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) # Data for recession shading recess <- tq_get("USRECM", get = "economic.data", from = "1800-01-01") tail(recess) ## # A tibble: 6 x 3 ## symbol date price ## <chr> <date> <int> ## 1 USRECM 2019-10-01 0 ## 2 USRECM 2019-11-01 0 ## 3 USRECM 2019-12-01 0 ## 4 USRECM 2020-01-01 0 ## 5 USRECM 2020-02-01 0 ## 6 USRECM 2020-03-01 0 recess_dat <- recess %>% arrange(date) %>% mutate(same = 1 - (price == lag(price))) %>% # Remove first row, an NA, for cumulative sum filter(date > min(recess$date)) %>% mutate(era = cumsum(same)) %>% # Filter only recessions filter(price == 1) recess_dat <- recess_dat %>% group_by(era) %>% # Unncessary, but to be sure.

item.title: The Beveridge Curve
item.description: Here are the latest data that depict the negative relationship between unemployment and job vacancies. The scatter plot of unemployment rates versus vacancy rates is known as the Beveridge curve. # Load packages library(tidyverse) library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) library(ggthemes) library(viridis) mygray <- "gray66" # Data series my_series <- c("JTSJOL", "PAYEMS", "UNRATE") dat <- tq_get(my_series, get = "economic.data", from = "1900-01-01") print(unique(dat$symbol)) ## [1] "JTSJOL" "PAYEMS" "UNRATE" # Data for recession shading recess <- tq_get("USRECM", get = "economic.

item.title: Labor Market Friday
item.description: Here are data from the latest Employment Situation. Unemployment rate or number of unemployed as a percentage of the labor force: # Load packages library(tidyverse) library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) library(ggthemes) mygray <- "gray66" ur <- tq_get("UNRATE", get = "economic.data", from = "2010-01-01") ur <- ur %>% mutate(series = "Unemployment rate") last_date <- max(ur$date) last_lvl <- ur$price[[which(ur$date == max(ur$date))]] ggplot(data = ur) + geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), size = 1.

item.title: Initial Claims
item.description: Here are initial-claims data, which were covered in a recent NY Times article. I try and replicate a few of the figures detailed in the article. Data on initial claims are available at FRED by browsing data by Category > Population, Employment, & Labor Markets > Weekly Initial Claims and selecting Initial Claims. Here is the R code for retrieving and plotting these data. Data on initial claims from March are highlighted in orange.

item.title: Happy Labor Market Friday!
item.description: Here are data from the latest Employment Situation. These graphs attempt to replicate those published by the NY Times. Unemployment rate or number of unemployed as a percentage of the labor force: # Load packages library(tidyquant) library(ggplot2) library(ggthemes) mygray <- "gray66" ur <- tq_get("UNRATE", get = "economic.data", from = "2010-01-01") ur <- ur %>% mutate(series = "Unemployment rate") last_date <- max(ur$date) last_lvl <- ur$price[[which(ur$date == max(ur$date))]] ggplot(data = ur) + geom_line(mapping = aes(x = date, y = price), size = 1.

item.title: Many models in R
item.description: Introduction This is an example of using R to run many regressions and collect a single regression coefficient from each model. The code uses R’s list-columns feature. Data library(forcats) library(tidyquant) date_start <- "1960-01-01" dat <- tq_get(c("UNRATE", "CPIAUCSL", "CPILFESL"), get = "economic.data", from = date_start) ur <- dat %>% filter(symbol == "UNRATE") %>% rename(ur = price) %>% select(-symbol) dat <- filter(dat, symbol != "UNRATE") Check that the unemployment-rate data are read in correctly:

item.title: Converting the Jekyll website to Hugo and Blogdown
item.description: MathJax.Hub.Config({ TeX: { equationNumbers: { autoNumber: "AMS" } } }); Table of Contents Introduction Footnotes $ \LaTeX{} $ Emojis Alerts and helpful hints Table of contents Introduction Using Jekyll as a static site generator with GitHug Pages on a Windows computer required setting up an Ubuntu environment to issue a jekyll serve command. Doing so became annoying. Another big selling point was the inclusion of R code in posts, a feature that I quickly became accostomed to after writing a couple of course websites in R Markdown and publishing them with GitHub Pages.

item.title: On the establishment survey
item.description: Are people who “run their own business” included in the Current Employment Statistics program? It depends.

item.title: What are the units of the GDP deflator?
item.description: What are the units of the current-year GDP deflator? The answer is base-year dollars / current-year dollars.

item.title: Ex ante versus ex post interest rates
item.description: The difference between ex ante and ex post interest rates has to do with the Fisher equation. If you took a couple more macro classes after ECON 402, you’d expect the Fisher effect to be expressed as the relationship between the nominal interest rate and expected inflation: $$ i_t = r_t + E_t \pi_{ t+1 }, $$ where \( E_t \) is the expectations operator conditional on all information available at time \( t \).

item.title: Example of dynamic inefficiency in the baseline OLG model
item.description: Reasonable parameter values are presented that give dynamic inefficiency in the canonical OLG model.

item.title: Economic growth
item.description: Life expectancy refers to life expectancy at birth. See http://www.gapminder.org/data/ for more details.

item.title: A functional equation
item.description: The 2015 midterm from 605 features a functional equation of the form $$ V(k,p,s) = \max \left\{ V_{\text{trade}},V_{\text{no trade}} \right\}, $$ where $$ V_{\text{trade}} = u(k^{N}) - pk^{N} + spk^{N} + \mathbb{E} \left[ V(k^{N}(1-\delta),p^{\prime},s^{\prime}) | p,s \right] $$ and $$ V_{\text{no trade}} = u(k) + \beta \mathbb{E} \left[ V(k(1-\delta),p^{\prime},s^{\prime}) | p,s \right] $$ This post goes through how you can establish that there exists a unique solution to the functional equation.

item.title: Balancing material
item.description: Here is a handout that goes through national accounting in a market structure that features two types of firms: capital-leasing and final-good firms. You can contrast this setup with the setup in question II of the ECON 607 final. Materials must balance in any economy.

item.title: The planning problem in search models
item.description: Here is a handout that goes through the algebra of a planning problem in Shimer’s manuscript, Labor Markets and Business Cycles. The setup of the problem is non-standard and unlike the problems we’ve solved all year, although this point is subtle. After laying out the problem, the non-standard approach is taken to first solve the problem following the lecture notes. Second, the problem is solved following the algorithm we’ve used all year; namely, writing the problem so that we choose next period’s state.

item.title: A worker's optimal search decision
item.description: A section on a worker’s optimal search decision was added to the ECON 607 Ottonello notes. They are included in section section 13, under the part titled “Odds and ends”.

item.title: Notes on classical monetary models
item.description: Notes on economies under the rubric of classical monetary models were added to the ECON 607 Ottonello notes. They are included in section section 9, which is new.

item.title: Practice with lag operators
item.description:
A few examples dealing with lag operators were added to the ECON 605 Leahy notes. They go through the “forward” and “backward” solutions to first-order linear difference equations and are included in section 2, “Practice with the lag operator,” which is new.

I also added Monday office hours from 1:00–3:00 pm in Foster library. They are listed under MacroSquad. We’ll try out this time and adjust accordingly.

item.title: ECON 607 notes uploaded
item.description: ECON 607 notes are uploaded. ðŸ˜‚ The ECON 607 Leahy notes are available here. The ECON 607 Ottonello notes are available here.

item.title: A few remarks on the 607 final
item.description: Notes on the 607 final were added to the ECON 607 Ottonello notes. They are included in section section 12, under the part titled “Odds and ends”.

item.title: Two minor corrections
item.description: Two minor corrections were incorporated into the 605 notes.

item.title: Determining whether capital jumps
item.description: A few people have asked me whether or not \( \tilde{k} \) jumps in the F2014 midterm. It does. Does that mean the stock of capital jumps? What about \(k\)?

item.title: OLG question
item.description:
A few comments were added to section P11 of the ECON 605 Stolyar notes that address the OLG question from the 2007 macro prelim. The economy is a special case of the economy discussed is section 8. The comments address the scope for rolling over government debt.

I also posted the suggested answers to the 605 midterm to the 605 Canvas website in the “Section stuff” directory.

item.title: ECON 605 notes uploaded
item.description: ECON 605 notes are uploaded and are available. The ECON 605 Stolyarov notes are available here. The ECON 605 Leahy notes are available here. I made several additions to both the Stolyarov and Leahy notes, which you might find helpful.

item.title: Welcome
item.description: Initial post: Hello world.

Here are initial-claims data, which were covered in a recent NY Times article. I try and replicate a few of the figures detailed in the article. Data on initial claims are available at FRED by browsing data by Category > Population, Employment, & Labor Markets > Weekly Initial Claims and selecting Initial Claims. Here is the R code for retrieving these data: # Load packages library(tidyverse) ## Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 3.
